title.narrative: A Civic Space that Enables Gender

description.narrative: Afghanistan is experiencing a complex and dynamic context; natural disasters are exacerbated by a changing climate and protracted heterogenous conflicts. Both internal and external actors and dynamics compound an uncertain political future where addressing genderequality and gains on women#s rights over the past 18 years are at risk. Almost two decades of international aid and development efforts appear at risk. International political entities continue to engage in both diplomatic and military efforts to end the war, most notably through direct talks between US and Taliban representatives (a reversal of previous policies). As of September 2019, the negotiations, which did not directly involve representatives of the Afghan government, have come to a standstill; however, the worryremains that a military withdrawal will be prioritised over a political settlement that protects the social, political, economic and humanitarian gains made since 2001.Existing inequalities between women, men, boys and girls, ethnicities, access to resources, etc., will be further exacerbated by the potential undermining of a democratic governance system. At this critical juncture for Afghanistan, civil society has a unique and crucial role to ensure effective inclusion and participation of Afghan citizens, especially women, youth and minorities in macro level systems like governance, economy, and society, as well as micro level individual agency. Hence, this Action aims to increase the capacity of CSOs to perform their role asindependent development actors more effectively and toenhance efforts to promote a conducive environment for CSOs.

participating-org.narrative:
Peace Training <(>&<)> Research Organisation (PTRO) Established in 2010 is a non-profit, non-political research and training organization based in Kabul and operational throughout Afghanistan. PTRO's vision is an Afghanistan which is at peace and stable at both national and sub-national levels, where the people have access to good governance and the rule of law.
PTRO s work focuses on four main areas; 1) Conflict resolution and peace building, 2) Linking informal and formal justice mechanisms, 3) Research toinform policyand programming, and 4) Promote participation in governance.
Through community based peace building programmes and the promotion of good governance PTRO aims to transform conflict that is contributing to local insecurity. We aim to build local capabilities in conflict resolution by providing training to established conflict resolution mechanisms such as shuras, jirgas, religious actors and informal court systems. By linking formal and informal justice mechanisms PTRO aims to promote the rule of law in Afghanistan. By working to promote unity between government and non-government actors we aim to support a more collaborative environment between the sub-national government and the local population.
In research PTRO's mission is toinform policy and programme debates using analysis from accurate, detailed field studies in areas which are often insecure and where the flow of information and understanding of the local environment is poor. This in-depth, contextually sensitive researchand analysis will help inform policy and programming in Afghanistan resulting in more meaningful, sustainable and long-lasting results from interventions across the country.
Peace Training and Research Org PTRO
